verses.text: If only you were like a brother to me, who nursed at my mother’s breasts! If I found you outside, I would kiss you, and no one would despise me.
verses.comment: In ancient Israel, public displays of affection were only acceptable between family members. The longing here shows the lover's desire for closeness without shame—a theme echoed in Christian teaching about the removal of shame through spiritual union (cf. Ephesians 5:25-27).

verses.text: I would lead you, I would bring you into my mother’s house—she who taught me. I would give you spiced wine to drink, the juice of my pomegranates.
verses.comment: Bringing the beloved into the mother's house hints at intimacy and union, paralleling the way the faithful are brought into the fullness of relationship with God. In a spiritual sense, it points to the guidance and nurture provided by tradition.

verses.text: His left hand is under my head, and his right hand embraces me.
verses.comment: The repeated image from Song 2:6 symbolizes both human love and, allegorically, divine embrace—a sign of protection and intimacy similar to Christ’s care for the Church (cf. John 10:28-29).

verses.text: I charge you, daughters of Jerusalem, do not arouse or awaken love until it wants to be.
verses.comment: The refrain warns to wait for the right time for love, reflecting the need for discipline and patience—both important virtues for spiritual maturity (cf. Galatians 5:22-23).

verses.text: Who is this coming up from the wilderness, leaning on her beloved? Under the apple tree I awakened you; there your mother conceived you, there she who gave you birth was in labor.
verses.comment: Emergence from the wilderness can symbolize Israel's exodus or spiritual journey. The reference to birth and awakening suggests both new beginnings and the nourishment found in close relationship, the way Christian tradition sees spiritual birth from 'above' (John 3:3-5).

verses.text: Set me as a seal upon your heart, as a seal upon your arm; for love is strong as death, jealousy is fierce as the grave. Its flashes are flashes of fire, a very flame of the LORD.
verses.comment: The imagery of seal represents unbreakable commitment—mirroring the indelible spiritual marks in Christian sacraments, and the fierce, total love God has for His people (cf. Isa. 49:16; 2 Cor. 1:22). 'Very flame of the LORD' shows love's divine origin, and the phrase’s rarity in the Old Testament points to the sacredness of covenant love.

verses.text: Many waters cannot quench love, neither can floods drown it. If someone gave all the wealth of his house for love, he would be utterly despised.
verses.comment: True love is priceless and unstoppable. This models the unshakable love of Christ that cannot be bought or destroyed (cf. Rom. 8:38-39; Eph. 3:17-19). The verse also alludes to total self-giving, a pattern for all believers.

verses.text: We have a little sister, and she has no breasts. What shall we do for our sister on the day she is spoken for?
verses.comment: The 'little sister' could represent a maturing believer or a group still growing in faith. The verse suggests the importance of nurturing and protecting the weaker or less mature among the faithful.

verses.text: If she is a wall, we will build on her a battlement of silver; but if she is a door, we will enclose her with boards of cedar.
verses.comment: This conditional image highlights the responsibility of strengthening and safeguarding purity and faithfulness, a theme echoed in the protection given to believers for their spiritual well-being and integrity.

verses.text: I was a wall, and my breasts were like towers. Then I was in his eyes as one who finds peace.
verses.comment: Maturity and stability lead to true peace—both in human love and spiritually in Christ (cf. John 16:33). The image of 'peace' is significant in biblical theology: a sign of right order and union.

verses.text: Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; he let out the vineyard to keepers; each one was to bring for its fruit a thousand pieces of silver.
verses.comment: The vineyard is a frequent image for God's people (Isa. 5:1-7; John 15:1). The reference to the keepers and fruitful yield anticipates Jesus’ teaching about stewardship and faithfulness.

verses.text: My vineyard, which is mine, is before me; you, Solomon, may have the thousand, and those who keep its fruit two hundred.
verses.comment: Claiming her own vineyard expresses personal dignity and autonomy—yet there is communal sharing of the harvest. Echoes the close relationship between individual believers and the larger body, pointing toward unity-in-diversity within a visible structure.

verses.text: You who dwell in the gardens, companions listen for your voice; let me hear it.
verses.comment: The beloved's desire to hear the voice of the other recalls the longing of God to hear the prayers and praise of His people—a relationship of communication and love (cf. Rev. 3:20).

verses.text: Hurry, my beloved, and be like a gazelle or a young stag on the mountains of spices.
verses.comment: The closing call is both a yearning for reunion and anticipation of fulfillment—paralleling the Church’s cry, 'Come, Lord Jesus!' The imagery suggests joyful expectation and final consummation.
